conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light. The shape and size of the shadow depend on the shape of the object and the position of the light source.
The position of the shadow is determined by the direction of the light rays relative to the object.
The shadows A, B, C, and D are currently cast behind the objects, indicating that the light source is positioned in front of the objects.
When the light source moves forward, it means the light rays will come from a position closer to the objects.

premise: When the light source moves forward, it means the light rays will come from a position closer to the objects.
conclusion: This change in the light source's position will affect both the position and the size of the shadows.

premise: As the light source moves forward, the shadows will shift closer to the objects.
conclusion: The light rays will intersect the ground at a steeper angle, causing the shadows to appear shorter and more directly behind the objects.

premise: When the light source is closer to the objects, the angle of the light rays relative to the ground increases.
conclusion: The size of the shadows will decrease.
